metadata.case_name: Post-Operative Rotator Cuff Repair — Retired Handyman with Protocol Tension
metadata.note: This case features a genuine clinical tension between two authoritative Dutch guidelines on immobilization duration. There is no single correct answer — the reasoning process is what matters.
metadata.unique_teaching_value: Navigating conflicting guideline recommendations; weighing re-tear risk vs stiffness risk; communicating with surgeon; managing patient expectations in post-operative rehabilitation

patient_profile.name: Henk Jansen
patient_profile.occupation: Recently retired handyman/klusjesman (retired 1 year ago). Still does extensive DIY projects at home and helps neighbors with maintenance tasks.
patient_profile.living_situation: Lives with wife Bep (60) in a terraced house (rijtjeshuis) in a small town. House requires ongoing maintenance — Henk has always done all household repairs and renovations himself.
patient_profile.hobbies: DIY projects (woodworking, painting, minor plumbing), fishing (freshwater, from bank — casting involved), playing cards with friends weekly, walking with wife
patient_profile.referral_reason: Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair right shoulder, 1 week post-operative. Referral for rehabilitation.

pre_operative_history.symptom_duration: 18 months of progressive right shoulder pain
conservative_management_attempted: Physiotherapy: 12 sessions over 4 months — exercise-based, moderate improvement in pain (NPRS 7 → 5) but persistent functional limitation with overhead activities and heavy lifting
Subacromial corticosteroid injection (x1, 3 months pre-op) — provided 6 weeks of significant relief, then gradual return of symptoms
Referral to orthopedic surgeon at 14 months

pre_operative_imaging.ultrasound: Full-thickness supraspinatus tear, 2.0 x 1.5 cm, moderate retraction
pre_operative_imaging.mri: Confirmed isolated supraspinatus tear, medium size. Infraspinatus and subscapularis intact. Goutallier grade 1 fatty infiltration of supraspinatus. No significant muscle atrophy. Mild superior labral fraying. No biceps pathology.
pre_operative_imaging.clinical_note: Medium-sized tear with good tissue quality — favorable surgical prognosis

pre_operative_status.functional_limitations: Unable to reach overhead, unable to lift >5kg above shoulder, unable to do DIY work involving overhead reaching (painting ceilings, fixing gutters), difficulty sleeping on right side

surgical_procedure.findings: Medium isolated supraspinatus tear (2.0 x 1.5 cm), good tissue quality, no significant retraction at time of repair. Infraspinatus and subscapularis intact. Mild superior labral fraying debrided. No acromioplasty performed.
surgical_procedure.repair_technique: Double-row suture bridge repair with 2 medial anchors and 1 lateral anchor. Good fixation achieved.
surgical_procedure.surgeon_notes: Straightforward repair. Good tissue quality. Tendon mobilized easily to footprint with minimal tension. Expect good healing potential. Recommend 6 weeks sling immobilization per our standard protocol.

post_op_protocol_prescribed.rationale_stated: Standard protocol for medium RC repair at our institution
post_op_protocol_prescribed.passive_rom_allowed: Pendulum exercises from day 1. Passive flexion to 90° and ER to 20° at 0° abduction with physiotherapist from week 2.

protocol_tension.description: The surgeon prescribed 6 weeks of sling immobilization based on institutional protocol. However, this patient's tear characteristics (isolated supraspinatus, medium size, good tissue quality, secure double-row fixation) meet the NOV 2025 qualifying criteria for 3-week immobilization. Additionally, the patient has significant stiffness risk factors (age 62, mild T2DM-related glucose intolerance, already restricted pre-operative ROM). The physiotherapist must navigate this tension.

nov_2025_position.recommendation: 3 weeks immobilization would be appropriate for this tear profile
qualifying_criteria_met: Secure surgical fixation — YES (double-row suture bridge)
nov_2025_position.evidence: Early mobilization studies show equivalent re-tear rates (~9%) for small-to-medium tears

snn_position.recommendation: 6 weeks baseline immobilization, or 4 weeks progressive variant
snn_position.progressive_variant_criteria: Small tear, good tissue quality, low stiffness risk — partially met (tear is medium, not small; stiffness risk factors present)

risk_factors_present: Impaired glucose tolerance / pre-diabetes (HbA1c 44 mmol/mol — just below T2DM threshold, but still a stiffness risk)
Male sex (lower stiffness risk than female, partially mitigating)
stiffness_risk_assessment.overall_stiffness_risk: Moderate — multiple risk factors present. Prolonged immobilization increases this risk.

protocol_tension.clinical_reasoning_challenge: The student/clinician must: (1) Recognize the tension between surgeon's 6-week protocol and NOV 2025 evidence, (2) Assess stiffness risk factors that argue for shorter immobilization, (3) Consider re-tear risk factors that argue for adequate protection, (4) Decide how to communicate with the surgeon, (5) Apply shared decision-making with patient. There is no single right answer — the quality of reasoning matters.
protocol_tension.coaching_prompt: The surgeon prescribed 6 weeks in a sling. You've read the NOV 2025 guideline suggesting 3 weeks may be sufficient for this tear profile. You've also identified stiffness risk factors. What do you do? Walk me through your reasoning.

current_status_1_week_post_op.patient_narrative: The surgery went well, the surgeon said. He told me I need to wear this sling for 6 weeks and then we start working on getting the movement back. I'm doing the pendulum exercises they showed me in the hospital. My wife Bep helps me get dressed and showered. I feel a bit useless — I'm not used to sitting around doing nothing. I can't even carry my own coffee cup with my right hand because of the sling. The pain isn't too bad actually — it's mainly sore at night when I roll over. The surgeon said it would take about 6 months before I can do my DIY work again. That's a long time. My neighbor asked me to help fix his garden fence next month and I had to say no. I just hope this surgery works — I tried physiotherapy before and it helped a bit but the shoulder never got properly strong again. I'm a practical man, I want to know exactly what I can and can't do, and when things will get better.

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: Should the physiotherapist follow the surgeon's 6-week immobilization protocol or advocate for earlier mobilization based on 2025 evidence?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: This is the central reasoning challenge. The physiotherapist should: (1) Review the evidence (NOV 2025 supports 3 weeks for this tear profile), (2) Assess patient-specific stiffness risk (moderate — argues for shorter immobilization), (3) Weigh re-tear risk (low for small-to-medium tears regardless of mobilization timing), (4) Communicate professionally with the surgeon — present the evidence and patient-specific factors, request shared decision-making, (5) NOT unilaterally change the protocol without surgeon discussion. The answer is a PROCESS, not a number.

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: How do you communicate with a surgeon who prescribed a protocol you believe may not be optimal?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: Professional, evidence-based communication: (1) Acknowledge the surgeon's expertise and standard protocol, (2) Present specific patient risk factors (age 62, pre-diabetes, pre-op ROM restriction), (3) Reference the 2025 evidence supporting earlier mobilization for this tear profile, (4) Propose a specific modification (e.g., transition to active-assisted at 4 weeks instead of 6), (5) Request discussion, not demand change, (6) Document the conversation and agreed plan.

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: What is the role of tramadol in this patient's current management?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: Tramadol is an opioid prescribed for post-operative night pain. Per 2025 evidence, opioids should not be first-line for shoulder pain. However, short-term post-operative use is clinically appropriate. The key is: (1) Plan for tapering within 2-3 weeks, (2) Monitor for dependency signs, (3) Transition to paracetamol-only as pain decreases, (4) Address night pain through positioning strategies to reduce pharmacological dependence.

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: How do you manage a patient who is more likely to do too much rather than too little?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: Henk's risk is over-activity. Strategies: (1) Frame restrictions positively — 'you're investing in the best possible outcome,' (2) Give very concrete rules — 'nothing heavier than a coffee cup with your right hand for X weeks,' (3) Use his practical nature — explain tendon healing biology in tangible terms, (4) Set clear milestones — 'at week X you can do Y,' (5) Involve wife Bep as ally in monitoring adherence, (6) Channel his energy into things he CAN do (walks, left-hand activities, planning future projects).

intervention_plan.treatment_approach: Post-operative criteria-based rehabilitation emphasizing balance between tissue protection and stiffness prevention. Clear communication with surgeon regarding protocol modification. Patient education on healing biology to manage expectations and prevent over-activity. Aligned with SNN Basisprotocol and NOV/FMS SAPS 2025.
intervention_plan.guideline_alignment: Hybrid approach: SNN Basisprotocol provides phase structure, NOV 2025 informs immobilization duration decision. No dedicated KNGF shoulder guideline.

critical_first_action.action: Contact surgeon to discuss immobilization duration
critical_first_action.rationale: Patient's tear profile meets NOV 2025 criteria for 3-week immobilization, and he has moderate stiffness risk factors (age 62, pre-diabetes, pre-op ROM restriction). The prescribed 6 weeks may increase stiffness risk without meaningful re-tear risk reduction for this tear size.
critical_first_action.proposed_communication: Present patient-specific factors (stiffness risk profile, tear characteristics meeting NOV 2025 criteria) and request shared decision-making on transitioning to passive/active-assisted ROM at 3-4 weeks instead of 6 weeks.
possible_outcomes: Surgeon agrees to 3-4 week transition — proceed with accelerated passive ROM
Surgeon prefers to maintain 6 weeks — respect decision but maximize passive ROM within allowed parameters and document stiffness risk monitoring plan
Surgeon requests review at 3-4 weeks to reassess — ideal shared decision-making outcome

interventions.dosage: 3-5 minutes, 3x/day. Relaxed, gravity-dependent. Forward/back, side-to-side, circles.
interventions.rationale: Gentle joint lubrication, prevent adhesions, pain modulation, patient engagement

interventions.dosage: 2x/week in clinic. Flexion progressing to 90° (then 120° by week 3-4), ER at 0° abduction to 20° (then 30° by week 3-4). Gentle, within pain tolerance.
interventions.rationale: Maintain and progress ROM within safe limits. Prevent capsular adhesions.
interventions.precautions: No combined abduction + ER. No behind-back IR. Stay within surgeon-approved limits.

interventions.dosage: Gentle scapular retraction in supported position. 10x 5-sec holds, 3x/day.
interventions.rationale: Maintain scapular muscle activation without loading RC repair

interventions.intervention: Elbow/wrist/hand active ROM and grip strengthening
interventions.dosage: Full ROM exercises 3x/day. Squeeze ball for grip maintenance.
interventions.rationale: Prevent disuse stiffness and weakness in distal joints

interventions.dosage: Ice pack 15-20 min, 3-4x/day, over surgical site with protection

interventions.details: Semi-reclined position (30-45° with pillow support) or supine with pillow under elbow. Avoid right side-lying. Sling on at night.
interventions.rationale: Reduce night pain and tramadol dependence

interventions.category: Patient education — healing biology and restriction rationale
interventions.intervention: Structured education on tendon-to-bone healing, why restrictions matter, and recovery milestones
interventions.rationale: Henk's risk is over-activity. He needs to understand WHY restrictions exist, not just WHAT they are. Use his practical nature — explain in concrete, mechanical terms he relates to.
key_messages: Think of the repair like gluing two pieces of wood together — the bond needs time to cure before you stress-test it. Right now we're in the curing phase.
At 3 weeks the repair has about 30% of its final strength. At 6 weeks about 50%. Full healing takes 12-16 weeks.
A re-tear from doing too much too soon means revision surgery, which has a much worse outcome than the original repair.
Your job right now is to be the patient patient. The sling isn't holding you back — it's protecting your investment.
We will give you progressively more to do. Each milestone means you've earned the next step.
interventions.education_for_wife: Involve Bep as ally — she can help monitor his activity levels and remind him of restrictions. Provide her with clear dos and don'ts.
interventions.coaching_prompt: How would you explain the healing timeline to a practical, action-oriented patient who is frustrated by restrictions? What analogies would you use?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.trap: Blindly following surgeon protocol without clinical reasoning
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Accepting the 6-week immobilization without considering patient-specific stiffness risk factors or 2025 evidence supporting shorter immobilization for this tear profile
